title: 110_hr5523
content: SEC. 2. LICENSE FEE ON INTERNET GAMBLING OPERATORS; LICENSEE INFORMATION REPORTING. This Act, known as the "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008," amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by adding a new subchapter to impose a license fee on internet gambling operators and require licensee information reporting. SEC. 2. The Act imposes a license fee on internet gambling operators under a new subchapter. Each licensed Internet gambling operator must pay a 2 percent license fee on all funds deposited into betting accounts each month. Winnings deposits are excluded from this fee requirement. The Internet gambling operator must pay a 2 percent license fee on all funds deposited into betting accounts each month. Winnings deposits are excluded from this fee requirement. Amounts paid as license fees will be deposited in the Treasury's general fund and treated as revenue. The fee is the exclusive obligation of the operator and cannot be deducted from bet amounts. The Internet gambling license fee is the exclusive obligation of the operator and cannot be deducted from bet amounts. The term 'Director' is defined in section 5382 of title 31, United States Code. The fee may be treated as an excise tax for administrative purposes. The Internet gambling license fee is considered an excise tax for administrative purposes, as prescribed by the Secretary through regulations. Additionally, a new section is added to provide information returns for persons subject to special provisions. "New section added for information returns of internet gambling operators." Every Internet gambling operator subject to section 4491 must provide required information to the Secretary as prescribed by regulations, including the operator's name, address, and other relevant details. Maintaining appropriate records is also necessary. The required information for Internet gambling operators includes name, address, tax information number, and details of wagers, winnings, losses, and tax withheld for each person. The information required for Internet gambling operators includes gross winnings, wagers, losses, tax withheld, account balances, and transaction details for each person. Additionally, a written statement must be provided to individuals with their name, address, and contact information. Every person making a return must provide a written statement to individuals with the name, address, and contact information of the person responsible for the return, along with the required information for the return. The statement must be given by January 31 of the following year. The written statement required for tax returns must be provided to individuals by January 31 of the following year. Clerical amendments are made to the table of subchapters for chapter 36. "Amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart A of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 to include a new item for returns of Internet gambling operators. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2008. Withholding from certain gambling winnings is addressed in Section 3." Amendments are made to include net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in any calendar year. No exemption for certain winnings except those described in paragraph (3)(D). Definitions in section 3402 are amended. Amendments to section 3402(q) include adding net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in any calendar year, with an exemption for winnings described in paragraph (3)(D). Definitions in subsection (q) are also updated to include terms like "proceeds of net Internet gambling winnings." The term 'Internet gambling winnings' refers to net winnings withdrawn from an account for Internet gambling. 'Net Internet gambling winnings' are gross winnings from Internet wagers with licensed entities, minus the amount wagered. The terms 'Internet' and 'wager' have specific meanings in this context. The amendment to section 3406 of title 31, United States Code, treats net Internet gambling winnings as reportable payments, with Internet gambling operators considered as payors and individuals placing wagers as recipients. The amendment treats net Internet gambling winnings as reportable payments, with operators as payors and individuals placing wagers as recipients. Effective after December 31, 2008. SEC. 4. WITHHOLDING OF TAX ON NONRESIDENT ALIENS. Tax on Nonresident Alien Individuals is amended to include net Internet gambling income. An exemption for certain gambling winnings now includes wagers placed over the Internet. The amendment includes net Internet gambling winnings in the tax withholding for nonresident alien individuals, with a threshold of more than $5,000 in a calendar year. The amendment includes net Internet gambling winnings in tax withholding for nonresident alien individuals, with a threshold of over $5,000 in a calendar year, effective for wagers placed after December 31, 2008. Tax on wagers is imposed, effective for wagers placed after December 31, 2008, with a threshold of over $5,000 in a calendar year. Persons placing wagers with unlicensed individuals are liable to pay taxes on those wagers. Wagers must be placed within the United States or its territories by US citizens or residents. These amendments are effective immediately. The amendments specify that wagers must be placed within the United States or its territories by US citizens or residents. These changes apply to wagers made after December 31, 2008.
